dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've been following a lot of news in the tech space, especially with self-driving. But, um, there's this really interesting, well, kind of *colossal* failure story that's come out recently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've been following a lot of news in the tech space, especially with self-driving. But, um, there's this really interesting, well, kind of colossal failure story that's come out recently.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And, like, the whole thing just fell apart. What's wild is, they made some pretty big claims early on, didn't they?

dialogue_turns.text: They did! They claimed they were the first to test an unmanned 18-wheeler on a U.S. highway. Turns out, [overlaps] that was completely...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] ...not true! Like, they were still using human drivers, because the tech was, uh, deemed too dangerous. And that Volvo test? Never even happened!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...not true! Like, they were still using human drivers, because the tech was, uh, deemed too dangerous. And that Volvo test? Never even happened!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Testing of a Volvo semi-truck loaded up with cameras and radar began June 16 on a 9.4-mile stretch of the Florida Turnpike in Orlando... This is literally the first time anyone has taken the person out of the vehicle on public highway, Seltz-Axmacher told Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And their CEO, Stefan Seltz-Axmacher, he's, like, trying to say his statements were taken out of context. But then he also admitted it was a "deliberate fabrication" about the truck navigating rest stops.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And their C E O, Stefan Seltz-Axmacher, he's, like, trying to say his statements were taken out of context. But then he also admitted it was a deliberate fabrication about the truck navigating rest stops.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The truck navigated a highway rest area, merged onto the Turnpike and changed lanes, maintaining an average speed of 55 miles an hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Unbelievable. And the whole teleoperations idea, where they'd control it from Jacksonville? That just, [pauses] that sounds pretty ambitious, but it also got shelved, didn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. And the whole teleoperations idea, where they'd control it from Jacksonville? That just, that sounds pretty ambitious, but it also got shelved, didn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Testing of a Volvo semi-truck... connected to a Starsky teleoperations center in Jacksonville... Starsky says it can move faster by adding a remote operator, connected via cellular networks, as a backup layer

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, apparently it was "impractical." And what's wild is, he said the company *never even planned to generate revenue* because the tech wasn't functional. I mean, wow.

dialogue_turns.text: So, they were basically just building something that wasn't going to work or make money? That's... a bold strategy, Cotton.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! And, um, they were trying to do remote operations, kind of like Waymo or TuSimple, but they found it "unworkable" for lane merges, even though latency wasn't an issue for rivals.

Competitors dont rely on remote operation, citing concerns about latency... Starsky says it can move faster by adding a remote operator... to handle tricky lane merges on the highway

dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] So they had different problems. And it sounds like the whole market for automated trucks isn't exactly booming right now anyway, is it?

dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. Self-driving *cars* are getting all the attention. Plus, highway driving is apparently really difficult to master for these systems. Waymo hasn't announced much, TuSimple's pilot failed...

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Starsky never even operated as a trucking service! They never hauled any actual loads in Florida or anywhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Starsky never even operated as a trucking service! They never hauled any actual loads in Florida or anywhere.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starsky also differs from rivals in that the company operates as a conventional trucking service, hauling loads in Florida and elsewhere often relying solely on human drivers.

dialogue_turns.text: Which meant, of course, no revenue. So they couldn't fund development. They literally got zero dollars from initial investment rounds.

dialogue_turns.text: A classic cautionary tale, wouldn't you say? What *not* to do in the autonomous vehicle space.
